about.title: About Me
about.content1: I lead the Intelligence Center at Grupo Bafar, where I transform data into strategic decisions for one of Mexico's largest food companies. My work combines analytical rigor with business vision: I design systems that automate the repetitive so teams can focus on what matters.
about.content2: My academic journey took me through Brazil, Colombia, and Argentina, culminating in a Master's in Data Science and Business Intelligence. My thesis explored the intersection of urban climatology and machine learning, showcasing how I apply advanced techniques to unconventional problems.
about.content3: My focus is on making data intelligence accessible for strategic decision-making, with the technical versatility to tackle everything from process automation to modeling and any challenge the business requires.

impact.title: Business-Oriented Results
impact.description: Development of initiatives that increase market opportunities, optimize processing times, and automate analysis workflows through intelligent systems and agile methodologies.

research.title: Applied Innovation
research.description: Focus on solving complex problems by combining advanced analysis techniques, machine learning, and research methodologies adapted to the business context.

leadership.title: Multisector Leadership
leadership.description: Experience managing technical teams in food, retail, and government sectors, implementing digital transformation and democratizing access to data-driven insights for C-suite strategic decision-making.

job1.title: Head of Intelligence Center
job1.description: Leading the Intelligence Center with multidisciplinary BI and market research teams. Responsible for data strategy across all group divisions (Food, Retail, Food Service, International). Implementation of agentic AI systems that reduced manual analysis by 70% and generated new market opportunities.

job2.title: Senior Data Analyst
job2.description: Led process optimization initiatives that increased operational efficiency by 18%. Development of executive dashboards for decision-making and data pipeline architecture that reduced processing times by 2300%.

job3.title: Data Analyst
job3.description: Resource allocation optimization in civilian support operations with multi-million dollar budgets. Cross-functional coordination with suppliers, logistics, and finance. Development of analysis models that improved aid distribution efficiency.

job4.title: Electoral Intelligence Analyst
job4.description: Development of data-driven acquisition strategies for federal electoral campaigns. Analysis of engagement KPIs, audience segmentation, and digital media investment optimization.

thesis.description: Using Machine Learning algorithms and Landsat 9 satellite imagery

research.phd: Actively exploring PhD opportunities in international programs

algorithms.title: ML Algorithm Comparison
algorithms.description: 6 algorithms evaluated - GTB outperforms Random Forest by +3.44%

1.name: Compact High-rise
1.description: Dense mix of tall buildings (+25m). High-density financial and commercial district.
1.climate: High solar absorption, significant nighttime heat retention, intense heat island.

2.name: Compact Midrise
2.description: 3-9 story buildings with dense configuration. Consolidated residential areas.
2.climate: High surface temperature, moderate-high heat retention.

3.name: Compact Low-rise
3.description: 1-3 story structures densely grouped. Traditional neighborhoods.
3.climate: Significant daytime heating, faster nighttime cooling.

4.name: Open High-rise
4.description: Isolated towers with ample green spaces between buildings.
4.climate: Lower thermal intensity, better ventilation, vegetation cooling.

5.name: Open Midrise
5.description: Balance between built surface and open spaces. BEST urban performance.

6.name: Open Low-rise
6.description: Single-family homes with gardens. Typical residential suburb.
6.climate: Low surface temperature, high cooling potential.

7.name: Lightweight Low-rise
7.description: Lightweight structures: markets, informal settlements. Variable materials.

8.name: Large Low-rise
8.description: Industrial buildings, shopping centers, warehouses. HIGHEST heat island intensities.
8.climate: Large absorbing surfaces, minimal vegetation. Mitigation priority.
8.examples: Central de Abastos, Vallejo Industrial Zone

9.name: Sparsely Built
9.description: Scattered layout in natural environment. WORST classification performance.

A.name: Dense Trees
A.description: Dense forest. MOST EXTENSIVE class of the study (21.6% of territory).
A.climate: MAXIMUM COOLING, evapotranspirative effect, continuous shade.
A.examples: Desierto de los Leones, Ajusco, Tlalpan Forest

C.name: Bush/Scrub
C.description: Shrub vegetation and scrubland. Ecological transition zones.
C.climate: Moderate cooling, sensitive to seasonal changes.

E.name: Bare Rock/Paved
E.description: Exposed rock or pavement. No vegetation.
E.climate: Extreme daytime heating, rapid nighttime cooling.

F.name: Bare Soil/Sand
F.description: Exposed soil or sand. Vacant lots, construction areas.
F.climate: Significant daytime heating, no evaporative effect.

G.name: Water
G.description: Surface water bodies. MAXIMUM thermal REGULATING effect.
G.climate: High thermal inertia, stable temperature, evaporative cooling.

congreso.title: CIMA 2025 Congress
congreso.subtitle: Presentation: LCZ Classification in CDMX
congreso.description: Presentation of the Local Climate Zones (LCZ) classification project for Mexico City using Landsat 9 imagery and Machine Learning techniques at the CIMA 2025 International Congress.
